name: Time Gentlemen, Please! and Ben There, Dan That! Special Edition  Double Pack
description: Ben There, Dan That! and Time Gentlemen, Please! are a couple of rip-roaring point-and-click adventure games . With tongue firmly in cheek, sit back, relax, and put your mind to work solving puzzles, and reading some very funny dialogue. It's like a book, only good!
minimum_requirements: OS: WindowsProcessor: Pretty much anything post-millennial, anything that runs DirectX 9.0c for particle effects.Memory: Anything over 256MB should do, anything that runs DirectX 9.0c for particle effects.Graphics:Any DirectDraw compatible. PixelShader 1.4/ DirectX 9.0c capable card required for particle effects. DirectX®: 9.0c required for particle effectsHard Drive: 150 MBSound: Any Windows-compatible soundcard

reviews.review_text: Ben and Dan are a pair of seasoned point-and-click adventurers who also happen to be your average British smartasses – though their jokes tend to be noticeably dumber (in a good way) and dirtier (again, in a good way). While trying to fix their TV in time for a relaxing episode of Magnum, P.I. they set off a chain of events which leads to the universe-hopping and time-jumping plots of Ben There, Dan That! and its sequel, Time Gentlemen, Please! The places and times they visit get sillier and sillier, but who really needs a deep plot when you've got good jokes?  Heavily influenced by classic point-and-click adventure games, both of the Ben and Dan games take their sense of humor and game feel from those old titles. Every line is a bad joke, an embarrassing pun, or an eye-rolling bit of meta-humor, and it's all a blast to read. The writing hits that perfect tone of 'smart in the dumbest way' and keeps the energy high with line after line of funny, stupid goodness. It's hard not to be impressed with the writers when the necessary evil of attempted item combinations yields lines that are just as funny as the main dialogue. There must be thousands of lines across both of these games, and I can't think of even one that I didn't enjoy. The art style works into this, too, with a rough look that is nevertheless very charming, colorful, and quite cohesive across every level.  Of course, while old adventure games were remembered for their writing and aesthetics, their gameplay isn't remembered quite so fondly. Unfortunately, Ben and Dan sometimes dive headfirst into those nasty pitfalls. For every few puzzles that goes along smoothly and logically, there will be a puzzle that will absolutely stump you, leading to far too much time mucking about in an overflowing inventory or with the finicky interface. The later puzzles of both games tend to throw logic out the window and require solutions that, while amusing once you know about them, are basically impossible to find without a walkthrough. Still, despite taking the bad with the good of the classic adventure genre, I'd say that the good is easily good enough to outweigh some awkwardness in design. Worthy new entries into a near-forgotten genre.

'Ben There, Dan That!', the first game, was actually the better of the two I think. They've both got the same awful (mostly on purpose) graphics, and annoying UI, but the writing was better in the first game. 'Time Gentlemen' had way more backtracking and the humour was less clever and more of the fart joke type of humour. Still, for the very, very cheap price I paid for this I can't complain. Definitely enjoyed 'Ben There, Dan That!' a lot more, although I can't say I recommend the games unless you can pick them up for roughly the ridiculous price I paid of 40c. Otherwise, there are better adventure games out there.

That game can make the time you spend playing it fun and pretty interesting. The game has a fine graphic and cool gameplay, the soundtrack is good. This was a unique experience playing that game and I liked it a lot.
Everyone should play this series...such a simple yet solid game..the story is so good, very funny...had a great time playing it.

Ben There, Dan That! and Time Gentlemen, Please! are a pair of the earlier point-and-click games on Steam.   Pros: Humor Cons: Graphics, Sound, Controls  These two low resolution protagonists, Ben and Dan, will somehow manage to save the world and be funny on their adventures, though not exactly in that order and probably not at the same time. It helps to have some experience with British humor and vocabulary (an aerial is an antenna, for example).  The graphics and sound are poor to say the least. Controls are no better; the majority of actions will be completed with the 'hand' yet it shares equal space with several less useful cursors. Of course, the difficulty is inflated in typical point-and-click fashion (thermos on lava, it all makes sense!).   With the number and availability of free and high quality point-and-click games nowadays, these two have difficulty standing out.  4/10

'Ben There, Dan That!' and 'Time Gentlemen, Please!' are 2 connected point & click adventures. The former's shorter, just an intro to the other which offers more of everything. If you enjoy playing sam and max games or puzzled games then this is for you!  Pros retro' graphics sort of unfriendly controls lots and lots of puzzles, which are sometimes non-sensical and/or require some pixel hunting crude, morbid and politically incorrect humor  Cons  no voice acting

Actually has a new (and consistently funny!) response to all the stupid things you're going to be clicking on, and you will be clicking on all the stupid things, and combining all the stupid things with every other stupid thing, because you want to find out what kind of dry, British comedy they've got lined up for combining an X-wing with loo cakes.  If you have any love for the British style of comedy and even the slightest tolerance (fondness not required) of point 'n clicks, this game is *definitely* worthy of your consideration, and most probably, purchase.
Like adventure games (especially LucasArts ones)? Like to laugh? Like to REALLY laugh? Buy this! You won't be disappointed!
Time Gentlemen, Please!  and  Ben There, Dan That!  are 2 fun little point and click adventures.
A traditional but hilarious point-'n-click adventure and a love letter to the genre. Well worth its price, beyond any doubt.
I'm glad I got this game for free from Bundlestars or else it would have felt like a waste of money.

Cheaper equivelent of Battlefield 4 with a great community and a large range of servers across the world. Combat is very realistic and customizable classes and emblems allow you to full express yourself regardless of gender or sexuality. Well done to the makers of this fantastic game.
It's a really nice point and click.

There are excellent games hidden behind the awful controls of these games. The humor is funny enough, but you need to click for the most basic things like walking across a room way too much to change the cursor, access Inventory and such. Maybe modern times made me lazy, but I recall that I didn't like this control scheme on the old Sierra games back in the day either which is why I barely finished any of them. I have the same issue with these games and not finishing them either. A verb menu or context-sensitive cursors would've helped alot here. On the upside, these kind of controls allow for some funny additional dialogue and obscure attempts that are absent in most modern games.  If you can look past the controls (I can't), you will find a strange and funny game that you might enjoy - and it's plenty 'o cheap to buy too!
The only game worldwide that employs 'Hitler´s   bloody stool  ' in a coherent puzzle chain.

Two ol' chaps, named Ben and Dan, get board one day, and decide '♥♥♥♥, let's take over the world'. They then create a crazy plot which involves time travel, interdimensional shenanigans, and game-developing dinosaurs. But, when they finally become rulers of the world, they realize they didn't want to rule it after all.  There, now you can move straight on to Time, Gentlemen, Please! and not have to spend 10 hours only to find out the blue tac needed to go on both the string AND severed hand.  Also, cow butt portals
I bought it on special, and Ben There Dan That was hilarious. Tedious at some points but I'm new to the point and click and style of game I still enjoyed it and would recomend it.
It's on sale 75p people. That's less than a 99 flake and they arnt even 99p anymore

I just saw that during the sale this pack of two AMAZING games are only 80 cents! That's less than... almost everything! They are both very fun old school quests with amazing sense of humour. Must have for everyone!

Well, I can officially say that I've used Hitler's bloody feces as an intergral tool in a video game. So there's that.  Time Gentlemen, Please is the sort of point-and-click adventure throwback that gives you a bunch of ridiculous items and asks you to find practical uses for them. Unlike a lot of the classics I thought the solutions to puzzles were genuinely clear and the few times I got stuck I felt like it was my own fault for not trying something obvious. There are enough puzzles that need you to find out a specific way to use an item rather that just using it in the right spot so it doesn't feel like a case of just using everything on eveything else until you stumble on the solution. On the whole it's on the easier side as far as these games go.  The writing in the game is more the star of the game than anything else. It's a pleasant change of pace if you get sick of adventure games that simply repeat 'I can't do that' for everything that isn't solution related. Attempting to combine most items or use them with most things in the world will give you unique dialogues for each action. Often with little hints towards solutions hidden in them. The humor alternates between referencing classic adventure games and toilet humor. At first it's pretty funny to examine random items and get rewarded with ♥♥♥♥-jokes, but it wears a little thin by the end and if you're new to adventure games all the references will probably fly over your head. It's definitely has an intended audience that will find it hilarious and the rest will probably scratch their heads. Overall I thought the jokes and one-liners were funny way more often than not, just by the sheer volume of them it's a little tiring by the end.  Also I'm not a fan of having to click through the different look/talk/use/move options, I'd rather be able to select the one I want, but it's not horrible by adventure game standards, just frustrating after a while.  Ben There, Dan That is also included in the package. It was a freebie game that was the blueprint for Time Gentlemen, Please. It's much shorter, but it still has the same mechanics and clever writing. The puzzles are pretty one-dimensional though though.
Ridiculously funny. If you love hilarious and difficult adventure games, these are well worth the price.

If you're a fan of Point & Click adventure games, particularly the LucasArts games, I think you'll enjoy playing these two. The first, 'Ben There, Dan That' is not great, suffering from a lot of linearity, but it was still fun enough to play through, and definitely worth playing as a preface to 'Time Gentlemen, Please'. This one had more polished writing, better puzzles, and felt more open than the predecessor. After the opening stages of the game, there are a lot of paths of exploration and puzzles available to be solved. I did get stuck a few times, but on all but one of them I was able to figure out the solution after taking a break from the game. One puzzle I did have to look up a walkthrough for, but it was only because what I thought was one game-object was actually two, and I needed to click on the 'second' one.  On the whole these were fun for me to play through, with many good puzzles and few bad ones.  Two things that may impact your enjoyment of the game. The humour is quite crude. If that's not your bag, then I think you'll find the writing grating. It's also quite a self-aware and self-referential game, which some people can't stand.
Cheeky, Good sense of humor, well worth the 24.5 cents, if you like point and click adventures anyway.

Absolutely must-buy indie game. You get 10 times of fun against what you pay.   Please, please, please, please .... buy this game and try it out. Simple point-n-click game but funny story. It contains crude and mature humor, aokay-ish puzzles to solve to progress, old-school feelings regarding graphics and sound - what do you expect from a $1 game (in sale)?

Plus: Possibly the greatest point and click adventures ever. Slight hint system that keeps you from wandering like a ducktard as many PACA games do. Humorous graphics, storyline, environment, puzzles, quips, jokes, references, and characters. Minus: Both game have and ending. :(  AMD Phenom II X6 1100T 3.3Ghz. 6GB DDR2 2.5TB 7200RPM, 16MB, SATA II 16MB/s Cable/N300 Wifi XFX 2GB Radeon 6950 Vizio 42' 1080P 3D LED
Funny and makes tons of references to the old LucasArts adventure games like Monkey Island. Some of the puzzles are just plain dumb, though. Worth a couple bucks, but probably not more than that.
its a.. good game. i guess.... maybe... no.. no its not....

I'm not sure what the people programming this where on, but the result wasn't worth it. Not by a far margin. It looks horrible, plays horrible and the dialogue font makes your eyes bleed after a while.
why did i even get gifted this
What other game has a Nazi Robot Dinosaur Clone Army searching for The Golden Coathanger of Doom? So good! ^ ^
Short, but entertaining, with puzzles that aren't too difficult to put together. The humor is also pretty good.
If your point and click adventure games don't have enough dinosaurs or Hitler, Time Gentlemen Please is for you.
Very witty with plenty of lightswitch jokes
Best thing I have bought for 0.35€ in my life.
best experienced on windows 95

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.
Great LucasArts style adventure games.

I originally wrote these off as lame fan indie games based on the screenshots but that was a mistake. They really made me miss the golden age of Lucasarts and Sierra. They are funny and actually quite challenging (though usually logical with the occasional adventure-game-logic puzzle).   If you like Monkey Island or Day of the Tentacle you can't go wrong, buy this pack right now.
Hitler, Dinosaurs, time travel, Cavemen. Did I mention robots? If you dont like point and clicks, dont play it, but if thats your style this game will take hours of your life.
Good adventure puzzle game.. :D  Only for people who likes 2D point click style!  Puzzles ( ★ 9,6 ) Other ( ★ 6,8 )

Well worth the money. The graphics may be far from AAA standard, but they have a charming nostalgic quality to them. Plus the writing and puzzles are great, with a fun story. I would have preferred voice-acting over reading everything, but it's still enjoyable, and a bargain!

These games are great little adventure games. Don't expect to be wowed by any of it, but they tell a funny story. They are like the point and click adventure games from back in the day only with worse graphics. You'll probably ragequit when you can't figure out what should be the simplest of puzzles, but when you get back to it and figure the puzzle out you'll realize it didn't really make much sense at all so your ragequit was justified. But the writing had me laughing so I put up with some of that. You will, too.
The humor in this game is great and although it lacks replay value, it's definitely fun.
Even better than 'Ben There, Dan That'
Not for me, luckily got it free
If you like point-and-click adventures and problem solving, you'll love this series. The gameplay is fantastic, and the writing is hilarious.
Lots of funny dialogue. Quite wierd, but interesting story. I got it too cheap for the enjoyment I got out of it.
